sentence: The return of a CEO with a sterling reputation can be a good thing for shareholders.
On Thursday,Procter & Gamble ( PG ) announced that Robert McDonald was out as CEO and his predecessor A.G. Lafley was back.
Lafley was CEO from mid-2000 to mid-2009.
Many see Lafley as a strong leader.
During the seven fiscal years before Lafley's reign as CEO, Procter & Gamble's revenue growth was in double-digits just one year, 1995.
Under Lafley, P&G's revenue growth was in double-digits for four years, with two years at 19% and 20% growth, respectively.
Under McDonald, revenue growth was stuck at 3% in each of the past three fiscal years, though the U.S. economy provided virtually no help in those years.
A few people, including hedge fund manager Bill Ackman of Pershing Square Capital Management, called for the replacement of CEO McDonald.
Yet, if an investor looks at price performance, it's hard to see McDonald as deserving the boot.
During Lafley's reign as CEO, P&G's stock rose 80% from mid-2000 to mid-2009, or 7% per year.
In the past four years under McDonald, P&G's stock rose about 59%, or 12% per year.
The quarterly dividend increased from 44 cents a share to 60.15 cents a share under McDonald.
That calculates to 8% annual growth in the payout.
If going back is better, some investors might wonder how better is better if it doesn't show up in the stock price or dividend.
Numbers never tell the future story, however.
Maybe the return of Lafley might help P&G.
At this point, that's not a given.
